root: ^Drone MSF-220 is engulfed by the swarm for what feels like an eternity. But it eventually detaches from the machine group and floats back to the jeep alone, external communication fields a washed-out periwinkle, the color of dejection.
^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Our little friend's been rejected by the swarm.

g-0: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: With our drone? Nothing. MSF's parameters are probably just incompatible with the swarms'.

s: ^INGRID: But it looks exactly the same as them.

g-1: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Yeah, but well, they're not the same inside. And a swarm's balance is delicate, our girl here would probably cause massive cascade failure if they did accept it.
g-2: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: They care, in their own way. A lot of these swarms, they're actually real big-hearted softies, they're willing to run a lot of risks to integrate a stranger.
g-3: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Just how they're wired. They're nicer than us, really. Pathologically empathetic. Group minds, less sense of self.
g-4: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Trust me when I say this, they're stupid nice sometimes. I've seen too many swarm die-offs happen because they couldn't stand to let another drone die of loneliness.
^(Johnny calls MSF-220 down and gently guides her into the calibration dock.)

s: ^INGRID: Are you adjusting them to fit this swarm?

g-5: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Nah, that'd be real mean of me. Evil, even. Compatibility runs real deep with drones, adjusting her for proper acceptance would require rewriting MSF's personality completely.
^(He falls silent for a moment as he squints at the array screens and adjusts something.)
^JOHNNY CRYPTO: I'm just making a few temporary changes, making our girl seem like REAL bad news to the swarm. The swarm equivalent of an axe murderer.
g-6: ^(Stragglers at the edge of the swarm are inching closer to MSF-220 in its dock, emitting curious clicks and whistles that sound almost like machine dolphin-call.)
^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Yep. Machines. Too nice by far.

s: ^INGRID: I get it. They're going to try and integrate her anyway, even if it means they're probably all going die because of it.

g-7: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Even if we left, they'd follow MSF-220 here across entire west coast to try and integrate her, if that's what it took. Even if it meant risking an 80%, 90% chance of mass swarm die-off. I'm telling you, group-minds don't think like us.
^Leaving another individual to be lonely - most swarms would rather die than accept that. Pathological empaths, is what they are.

s: ^INGRID: That's...really sweet. Would they really do that? Just for our misfit drone?

g-8: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: Almost certainly. Not unless I do what I'm doing right now, which is painting a big temporary "▓▓▓▓ OFF" on her exterior communication net. One thing swarms can't stand, it's open antipathy.

s: ^INGRID: I see why. Still, it's sad...

c-9: ^(The calibration dock releases a satisfying ping and releases the drone, which is now an angry mauve. The stragglers that were approaching it immediately slink away, MSF-220 whirls and clicks in dismay.)

g-9: ^JOHNNY CRYPTO: (Sighing) Well, there's four hundred registered swarms in the Pacific North-West alone, and we've only seen four so far. We'll find a home for this little misfit.

s: ^(You open the door to the car and usher the drone inside.)

c-10: ^Its movements seem morose, resigned. You have flashbacks to when you were always the last kid picked for teams back in highschool gym class, forever the odd one out.)

c-11: ^<i>(Johnny swings himself into the shotgun seat and pats MSF-220 fondly on the top of its rusted exterior casing. It purrs and clicks approvingly.)
